questions.question: The evening was …………………. cold.
questions.description: Bitter is an adjective and bitterly is an adverb. We use adverbs to modify verbs and adjectives.

questions.question: I couldn’t help ………………….. at the joke.
questions.description: The expression 'couldn’t help + ing' has the same meaning as the expression 'couldn’t help but + infinitive without to'.

questions.question: I have never seen a more …………………. cricket match.
questions.description: A match cannot be excited. An exciting match keeps spectators excited.

questions.question: This movie is ……………….. interesting.
questions.description: Very and so are possible here. Too has a negative meaning.

questions.question: I am ……………… annoyed to hear this.
questions.description: Very and so are not followed by to-infinitives.

questions.question: He was ………………. tired that he could barely stand.
You must not waste your ………………. earned money.
questions.description: The correct expression is 'hard-earned money'. Hardly is similar to scarcely.

questions.question: No one can write as ……………….. as he does.
questions.description: Neat is an adjective and neatly is an adverb. We need an adverb to modify a verb.

questions.question: I cannot by ……………… means allow you to go.
The fish tasted …………………
questions.description: Taste is a copular verb. After copular verbs we use adjectives, not adverbs.

questions.question: The problem looked ………………….
questions.description: Look is a copular verb. After copular verbs, we use adjectives, not adverbs.

questions.question: I ………………. having read a more enjoyable book.
questions.description: The use of never for not is incorrect in many cases.
